column1: Make Meatballs Sing: A Loving Illustrated Celebration of the Radical Nun, Artist, Teacher, and Activist Corita Kent
column3: Doing and making are acts of hope, and as that hope grows we stop feeling overwhelmed by the troubles of the world. We remember that we — as individuals and groups — can do something about those troubles.

column1: Halloween’s Forbidden Fruit: Michael Pollan on Gardening as Radicalism and the Scandalous Botanical Origin of the Broomstick in Flying-Witch Legends
column3: For most of their history... gardens have been more concerned with the power of plants than with their beauty — with the power, that is, to change us in various ways, for good and for ill.

column1: Every Loss Reveals What We Are Made of: Blue Bananas, Why Leaves Change Color, and the Ongoing Mystery of Chlorophyll
column3: We reach forth and strain every nerve, but we seize only a bit of the curtain that hides the infinite from us.

column1: Blessing Sound, Blessing Light: David Whyte’s Poems for the Small Miracles of Presence that Awaken Us to the Wonder of Being Alive
column3: Cinematic songs of praise for the visible invisibilities and the silent symphonies that make life worth living.

column1: A General Theory of Possibility: The Abstract Art of Otherwise and the Physics of Resilience
column3: As always happens with contradictions, something in the assumptions has to give... Declaring something impossible leads to more things being possible.

column1: Becoming the Marginalian: After 15 Years, Brain Pickings Reborn
column3: Notes from the odyssey of ongoingness, notes for the symphony of aliveness.

column1: Kinship: Ursula K. Le Guin’s Love Poem to Trees, the Interleaving of Life and Death, and the Eternal Flame of Being
column3: A lyrical reminder that the word for world is forest and the feeling of forest is love.

column1: How (Not) to Love: Unbreaking Our Hearts by Breaking Our Patterns, or, Chekhov’s Insight into the Most Disquieting and Liberating Truth about Love
column3: We want to believe that love is singular and exclusive, and it unnerves us to think that it might actually be renewable...

column1: The Century-Old Field Guide to Wonder and the Forgotten Woman Who Laid the Groundwork for the Youth Climate Action Movement
column3: All things seem possible in nature; yet this seeming is always guarded by the eager quest of what IS true. Perhaps half the falsehood in the world is due to lack of power to detect the truth and to express it.

column1: The Art of Solitude: Buddhist Scholar and Teacher Stephen Batchelor on Contemplative Practice and Creativity
column3: Here lies the paradox of solitude. Look long and hard enough at yourself in isolation and suddenly you will see the rest of humanity staring back.

column1: Alain de Botton on the Myth of Normalcy and the Importance of Breakdowns
column3: Crisis... is an attempt to dislodge us from a toxic status quo and constitutes an insistent call to rebuild our lives on a more authentic and sincere basis.

column1: The Beauty of the Overlooked: Philip Henry Gosse’s Stunning 19th-Century Illustrations of Coastal Creatures and Reflections on the Delicate Kinship of Life
column3: These objects are, it is true, among the humblest of creatures that are endowed with organic life... Here we catch the first kindling of that spark, which glows into so noble a flame in the Aristotles, the Newtons, and the Miltons of our heaven-gazing race.

column1: Thich Nhat Hanh on the Art of Deep Listening and the 3 Buddhist Steps to Repairing a Relationship
column3: The intention of deep listening and loving speech is to restore communication, because once communication is restored, everything is possible.

column1: Funeral March for the First Cosmonaut: Artist, Poet, and Philosopher Etel Adnan’s Stunning Painted Poem About Life, Death, Loneliness, and Our Cosmic Redemption
column3: In the beginning was the white page. In the beginning was the Sufi in orbit... In the beginning was color. In the beginning was music.

column1: MLK’s Lost Lectures on Technology, Alienation, Activism, and the Three Ways of Resisting the System
column3: There has always been a force struggling to respect higher values. None of the current evils rose without resistance, nor have they persisted without opposition.

column1: Broken Tulips: How a Virus Gave the World’s Most Prized Flower Its Beauty
column3: An epochal intersection of art and science, ecology and culture, psychology and microbiology.

column1: A Process for the Transfer of Energy and Feeling: George Saunders on the Key to Great Storytelling
column3: What a story is 'about' is to be found in the curiosity it creates in us, which is a form of caring.

column1: September 28, 1951: Alan Turing, the World’s First Digital Music, and the Poetry of Possibility
column3: A hoot, a hummingbird, and an electronic hymn for the modern world.

column1: Love, Death, and Whitman: Poet Mark Doty on the Paradox of Desire and the Courage to Love Against the Certitude of Loss
column3: Isn’t the flesh a way to drink of the fountain of otherhood, a way to taste the not-I, a way to blur the edges and thus feel the fact of them?... You need to both remember where love leads and love anyway; you can both see the end of desire and be consumed by it all at once.

column1: Place, Personhood, and the Hippocampus: The Fascinating Science of Magnetism, Autonoeic Consciousness, and What Makes Us Who We Are
column3: Often the places we grow up in... influence how we perceive and conceptualize the world, give us metaphors to live by, and shape the purpose that drives us.

column1: What Makes You You Makes the Universe: Nobel Laureate Erwin Schrödinger on Quantum Physics, Vedanta, and the Ongoing Mystery of Consciousness
column3: This life of yours which you are living is not merely a piece of the entire existence, but is in a certain sense the whole.

column1: Drawing a Tree: Uncommon Vintage Italian Meditation on the Existential Poetics of Diversity and Resilience Through the Art and Science of Trees
column3: A subtle sylvan celebration of how our hurts and our healings shape the singular beauty of our character.

column1: The Geometry of Grief: Mathematician Michael Frame on How Fractals Help Fathom and Move Through Loss
column3: The distance between here and there is the answer to the wrong question.

column1: When Your Parents Are Dying: Some of the Simplest, Most Difficult and Redemptive Life-Advice You’ll Ever Receive
column3: Death makes human beings seem like very small containers that are packed so densely we can only be aware of a fraction of what's inside us from moment to moment.

column1: The Geometry of Grief: A Mathematician on How Fractals Can Help Us Fathom Loss and Reorient to the Ongoingness of Life
column3: The distance between here and there is the answer to the wrong question.

column1: Women in Trees: Sweet and Subversive Vintage Photographs of Defiant Delight
column3: The chance-anthropology of a secret tribe.

column1: Gravity, Grace, and What Binds Us: Poet Jane Hirshfield’s Timeless Hymn to Love and the Proud Scars of the Heart
column3: ...and when two people have loved each other see how it is like a scar between their bodies, stronger, darker, and proud...

column1: Shifting the Silence to Find the Meaning: 95-Year-Old Artist, Poet, and Philosopher Etel Adnan on How to Live and How to Die
column3: The universe makes a sound — is a sound. In the core of this sound there’s a silence, a silence that creates that sound, which is not its opposite, but its inseparable soul... Silence is a flower, it opens up, dilates, extends its texture, can grow, mutate... It can watch other flowers grow and become what they are.

column1: Life, Death, and What Fills the Interlude with Meaning: Nathaniel Hawthorne’s Touching Diary Reflections on His Dying Mother and His Five-Year-Old Daughter
column3: I saw my little Una... so full of spirit and life that she was life itself. And then I looked at my poor dying mother, and seemed to see the whole of human existence at once, standing in the dusty midst of it.
